1.label: eat
notes: original_question: How are your eating habits? Do you eat your meals on schedule?
original_resp: I don't usually have my meals on time
original_question: How are your eating habits? Do you eat your meals on schedule?
original_resp: I don't usually have my meals on time

followup_resp: My work schedule is quite unpredicatable which often causes me to miss my meals or have them at odd hours. Addtionally, I sometimes get so engrossed in my work that I forget to eat. This irrefgular eating pattern has started to affect my health.

followup_resp_1: rv_validation: VALIDATION: It makes sense that with a quite unpredictable work schedule and getting so engrossed in work, meals end up at odd hours or get missed, and now this irregular eating pattern is affecting your health. That is tough, and you are not alone in this.

A few gentle, flexible ideas you could try:
- Use flexible meal windows instead of strict times (e.g., a morning, mid-day, and evening window). If work is hectic, aim to eat something within each window.
- Set simple reminders or calendar nudges on your phone or computer to pause and check: Did I eat or drink water?
- Keep portable, balanced snacks within reach (nuts, yogurt, fruit, cheese sticks, protein bars) for when you forget to eat.
- Prep 1-2 easy go-to meals on calmer days (or keep ready-to-eat options) so you can grab food fast when your schedule shifts.
- Pair eating with an existing work habit (e.g., after your first meeting, after sending a report, or when you refill your water).
- If possible, block a short 10-15 minute buffer in your calendar as a non-meeting time to eat, even if the exact time moves.

Since you mentioned it has started to affect your health, consider a quick check-in with a healthcare professional to rule out any issues and get personalized guidance. Would you like help building a simple plan for your next week that fits your unpredictable days?
